communication_tips.title: Better Communication with Your Loved One
communication_tips.hook: Transform difficult conversations into meaningful connections

slides.title: Use Simple, Clear Language
slides.content: Speak slowly and use familiar words. Avoid complex explanations that might cause confusion or frustration.

slides.title: Listen with Your Whole Body
slides.content: Make eye contact, lean in, and show you're engaged. Non-verbal cues speak louder than words.

slides.title: Validate Their Feelings
slides.content: Say 'I understand this is hard' instead of 'Don't worry about it.' Acknowledge their emotions.

slides.title: Ask Open-Ended Questions
slides.content: Instead of 'Are you okay?' try 'How are you feeling right now?' Give them space to express themselves.

slides.title: Be Patient with Silence
slides.content: Don't rush to fill quiet moments. Sometimes people need time to process and respond.

burnout_signs.title: Experiencing Caregiver Burnout
burnout_signs.hook: Recognizing the warning signs could save your wellbeing

slides.title: You Feel Emotionally Drained
slides.content: Even simple tasks feel overwhelming. You're running on empty and struggling to find motivation.

slides.title: You're Isolating from Friends
slides.content: You've stopped reaching out to your support network. Social connections feel like too much effort.

slides.title: You're Neglecting Self-Care
slides.content: When did you last do something just for you? Basic needs like eating well or sleeping become secondary.

slides.title: You Feel Resentful
slides.content: Guilt-inducing thoughts like 'Why me?' or anger toward your loved one are becoming frequent.

slides.title: Your Health is Suffering
slides.content: Headaches, stomach issues, or getting sick more often. Your body is telling you to slow down.

guilt_phrases.title: Guilt-Inducing Phrases
guilt_phrases.hook: Words have power - choose ones that heal, not harm

slides.say_this: "I can see you're struggling. How can I help?"
"Your feelings are valid. Let's work through this together."
slides.why: Validates emotions instead of dismissing them
Shows empathy instead of creating shame

slides.say_this: "This is really unfair, and I'm here with you."

dementia_myths.title: Dementia Care
dementia_myths.hook: Busting myths that harm families and patients

slides.reality: The person is still there, just experiencing the world differently. Meaningful connections remain possible.
slides.impact: This belief leads to social isolation and depression

slides.reality: Exercise, social engagement, and cognitive activities can significantly impact quality of life and progression.
slides.impact: Hopelessness prevents families from seeking beneficial interventions

slides.reality: It impacts judgment, language, spatial awareness, and personality. Understanding this helps with better care.

slides.myth: You shouldn't correct someone with dementia
slides.reality: Gentle redirection and validation work better than lies or harsh corrections.
Care needs vary greatly. Many people live independently with support for years.
slides.impact: Premature loss of independence and dignity

self_care_journey.title: Finding Balance
self_care_journey.hook: One caregiver's path from burnout to sustainable care

slides.title: The Breaking Point
slides.content: Sarah hadn't slept through the night in months. Caring for her mom with Alzheimer's was consuming every moment of her life.

slides.title: The Wake-Up Call
slides.content: When Sarah collapsed from exhaustion at the grocery store, she realized she couldn't pour from an empty cup.

slides.title: Asking for Help
slides.content: Starting with just 2 hours of respite care per week felt like failure. Actually, it was the first step toward sustainable caregiving.

slides.title: Building Support
slides.content: Joining a caregiver support group connected Sarah with others who understood. She wasn't alone anymore.

slides.title: The New Normal
slides.content: Six months later, Sarah had regular respite care, therapy sessions, and boundaries. Her mom was happier too.

medication_tips.title: Managing Medications Safely
medication_tips.hook: Simple systems that prevent dangerous mistakes

slides.title: Use a Pill Organizer System
slides.content: Weekly pill boxes with AM/PM compartments reduce confusion and missed doses. Label clearly with day and time.

slides.title: Keep an Updated Med List
slides.content: Include dosages, prescribing doctors, and what each medication treats. Share copies with all care providers.

slides.title: Set Consistent Timing
slides.content: Link medications to daily routines like meals or bedtime. Use phone alarms as backup reminders.

slides.title: Know Drug Interactions
slides.content: Use one pharmacy when possible. They can catch dangerous combinations that multiple providers might miss.

slides.title: Monitor Side Effects
slides.content: Keep a simple log of changes in mood, appetite, or behavior. Share concerns with doctors promptly.

respite_care.title: Finding Quality Respite Care
respite_care.hook: Getting the break you need without the guilt

slides.title: Start with Small Steps
slides.content: Begin with 2-3 hours of care to test compatibility. Gradual transitions work better than sudden changes.

slides.title: Check References Thoroughly
slides.content: Ask for at least 3 recent references. Verify certifications and run background checks through agencies.

slides.title: Create Detailed Care Instructions
slides.content: Include routines, preferences, emergency contacts, and behavioral triggers. The more info, the better the care.

slides.title: Observe Interactions
slides.content: Watch how the caregiver connects with your loved one. Trust your instincts about the relationship dynamic.

slides.title: Plan Your Respite Time
slides.content: Use breaks for rest, errands, or activities that restore you. Don't feel guilty about enjoying yourself.

hospital_advocacy.title: Advocating in Hospital Settings
hospital_advocacy.hook: Ensuring your loved one gets the best possible care

slides.title: Bring a Complete Medical History
slides.content: Include current medications, allergies, recent changes, and baseline functioning. Print multiple copies.

slides.title: Ask for the Charge Nurse
slides.content: When concerns aren't addressed, speak with the charge nurse or nurse manager. Document everything.

slides.title: Request a Care Conference
slides.content: Get all team members together to discuss treatment plans. Ask questions until you understand everything.

slides.title: Stay with Your Loved One
slides.content: If possible, maintain a presence. Your advocacy and observation can prevent medical errors.

slides.title: Know Your Rights
slides.content: Understand patient rights, discharge planning timelines, and when to request a second opinion.

financial_planning.title: Financial Planning for Long-Term Care
financial_planning.hook: Protecting your family's financial future while providing care

slides.title: Understand Insurance Coverage
slides.content: Review Medicare, Medicaid eligibility, and long-term care insurance. Know what's covered and what isn't.

slides.title: Organize Important Documents
slides.content: Gather Social Security cards, birth certificates, insurance policies, and financial statements in one place.

slides.title: Consider Legal Protections
slides.content: Explore power of attorney, living wills, and trusts. Get legal advice before assets need protection.

slides.title: Track All Care Expenses
slides.content: Keep receipts for medical equipment, modifications, and care services. Many are tax-deductible.

slides.title: Plan for Future Costs
slides.content: Research care facility costs, home health rates, and equipment needs. Budget for increasing care levels.

depression_signs.title: Struggling with Caregiver Depression
depression_signs.hook: Depression in caregivers is common and treatable

slides.title: You've Lost Interest in Things You Enjoyed
slides.content: Hobbies, social activities, or simple pleasures no longer bring joy. Everything feels flat and meaningless.

slides.title: You Feel Hopeless About the Future
slides.content: It feels like things will never get better. You can't imagine finding happiness or relief again.

slides.title: You're Having Sleep Problems
slides.content: Either can't fall asleep, wake up frequently, or sleep too much. Rest doesn't make you feel better.

slides.title: You're Eating Very Differently
slides.content: Either no appetite and weight loss, or eating for comfort and gaining weight. Food has lost meaning.

slides.title: You Think About Death or Dying
slides.content: Whether your own or wishing the situation would just end. These thoughts are a red flag for professional help.
